page.lettertext:
fol.34r
May yt please yo
r
good L. In my former l
re
s of w
ch
I
writt my last the 4
th
of this moneth I have made
rehersall to yo
r
L. of all that hethertoo hath passed aswell in
publik consultation as in private discourses, w
ch
I have had
in this place in regard of the treaty desired by the Empero
r
.
I did my best endevor to have stopped
e licence of Mons
r
Bilandt
but becaus yt was caried w
th
consent of
e most it could not be
prevented. He remaineth heere attending
e meeting of
e States
whose coming is expected in 5 or 6 daies, & I hope
they will devise w
th
in litle of theyr coming, to dispatche him
in good sort. I knowe not well for my self when they put mee to
my voice, what course I may propose, to concurre as I would
w
th
her Hig
nes
intent. But I think there wilbe time to heare
from yo
r
L, before they will coming to
e giving of theyr answer.
If it fall out otherwise I know not wh
r
uppon I may better
insist, th
e
to move th
e
as I did before the arrival of Mons
r
Bilandt, to conceave a good l
re
to
e Empero
r
him self, & to
signify all
e reasons that have caused them hethertoo to
refuse his Embassado
rs
: w
th
a summary declaration of all
e
domage & p
r
judice, w
ch
they have formerly sustained by the
practises of Embassado
rs
in
e like pretended treaties: & to notefy
directly how well they stand affected to
e offer of a peace
so it be w
th
out fraude, & w
th
fitt conditions including theyr
neyboures aswell as themselves, & all such clauses of assurance
as the p
nt
estate of theyr cause doth require. I should judge it
expedient that there were coppies of it sent to the Princes of Germany
& to others to meet w
th
that report, w
ch
is now very rife,& wilbe
more in every month if it be not p
r
vented by considerate dealing.
That they are an uncivil & a barbarous people & an enemy to
peace, having no dessigne before theyr eyes, but to begger other
Provinces to enriche themselves, through the benefit of theyr traffique
w
ch
is all in a manner derived hether, & waxeth greater by these
warres th
e
it hath bin heertofore, in peaceable times. By
addressing an answere to this effect, they shall not onely free
them selves of those hard imputations, w
ch
may make them very
odious to oth
r
nations abroade, but the people of this countrey
shalbe by it somewhat more engaged against these treaties of
e
Enemy, by publishing in writing such actes of opposition.
fol.34v
Knowing nothing more then I doe at this p
nt
, how her [Majesty in]
this matter would be
s
rved by mee, I cannot yet under[stand]
what waie of
ceeding can be lesse prejudiciall to her [Majesty or]
to them. I sent yo
r
L. heertofore
e transcript of [a]
l
re
w
ch
was written by D. Casimire to
e Empero
r
, bea[ring date]
the 24 of Novem
b
& nowe
e answere thereof, being come [to my]
hand
I send it heerinclosed translated out of Dutche.
It is written from Collen that
e Embassado
rs
left [at Brussels]
are all de
ted some to Collen, & some to theyr houses [near to]
Collen, & that there they will remaine till the an[swer]
be given to him: that ys heer. There are also l
re
s [from]
Collen that
e Baron of Barenstein, who is
e chi[ef of]
those Embassado
rs
doth levy at this instant a regiment of [Lance]
Knightes for
e K. of Spaine, But yt is not beleeved [by Mons
r
]
Bilandt. The forces appointed for the
s
vice of France, [can by]
no meanes advance theyr voyage thether for want of a w[ind.]
Howbeit the companies are in garrison neer to their sh[ippes,]
& shall p
nt
ly away w
th
e very first winde. If theyr [coming]
to
e King shalbee greatly to his benefit, according to that [motion which]
I lastly made unto you, I thinke her Hig
nes
autority, [and the]
instance of
e King, may procure theyr continuance for [all this]
sommer, & get at
e lest 2000 more. For
e happ[y success]
of
e last yeares warres hath so apparantly assured the [body of]
these provinces, that if Parma & his forces continew s[till in]
France, they may easily keepe theyr owne by way of defence [with the]
help of a few, & employ
e remainder to
e moste annoy[ance of]
e enemy. But wheth
r
it be convenient I am wholy [to refer]
it to yo
r
L. consyder
ao
n. For I know my want of [judgement]
in affaires of this quality, but if her Ma
ty
&
e K[ing be]
willing unto yt, I doe think assuredly, that there join[t and urgent]
sute wilbe greatly respected: if
e King in spetiall [will be]
earnest for himself. For this is very evident and ob[served]
heer of all, that howsoever c
r
taine
sons of
e principal [in this]
place be seldome times favourers of her Hig
nes
petitions [yet in causes]
of
e King, they do openly affectate, & every day more, [an]
extraordinarie forwardnes w
ch
they shew in all theyr actions [and speeches]
& cariages whatsoever. & yet by all that I can ge[sse, it]
doth not so much
ceed of a good affection to
e K[ing, as of]
a politicke desire in a case of oppression, w
ch
they [are]
